question.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the light reactions of photosynthesis?

options.text: <math><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>680</mn></mrow></msub></math> and <math><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>700</mn></mrow></msub></math> are the reaction centres of PS-I and PS-II respectively.
Light energy provides energy for the photolysis of water through excitation of the reaction center of PS-II.
NADPH is not produced in cyclic electrons transport in light reaction.
Reactions of the two photosystems are needed for the reduction of NADP.

solution.text: In photosystem-I (PS-I), the photocenter is a special chlorophyll-a molecule called <math><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>700</mn></mrow></msub></math>. It is active in both red and far-red light, while a very small amount of special form of chlorophyll-a called <math><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>680</mn></mrow></msub></math> constitutes the reaction center of photosystem-II (PS-II), which is inactive in far-red light (beyond 680 nm).
